body: For `AvroUtils` I think you can just tag it with `javax.annotation.Nonnull`. That should make the FindBugs warnings go away.
@sahilTakiar It is defined as nullable in the Guava interface, this is the contract of the API.

I tested it, it is working as expected. The only change I had to make was to remove the copying of `TaskState` it seems that the `Fork` class is already mutating the `TaskState` object in a very other places, and there are some features that depend on the ability of mutating `TaskState`. Basically, a bunch of tests failing when I added the copying of `TaskState` so I removed it.

LGTM besides the minor comment. Unfortunately, I cannot find a cleaner way to do this than to use the home directory of the `FileSystem` object. Ideally `FileSystem.equals()` would be sufficient for this, the `equals()` method doesn't seem to be overloaded in the `FileSystem` class, or any of its subclasses.

Merging this for now since it is a blocker. I will address the comment in another PR.
LGTM other than the minor comments.

LGTM. Merge after build passes.
Add the new prop to wiki
LGTM other than the minor comments.
@pcadabam please hold on this until we have a thorough understanding the problems and requirements here.

@liyinan926 The described error was experienced when I used the job history store.
This schema change allows Gobblin writes to the gobblin_job_executions & gobblin_task_executions tables on my MySQL instance without this error.

@omok one benefit of using `TIMESTAMP` is that MySQL converts `TIMESTAMP` values from the current time zone to UTC for storage, and back from UTC to the current time zone for retrieval. It seems the zero value `0000-00-00 00:00:00` is acceptable and seems a good choice for a default value. Can you try using that for `DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP`?

Just a quick comment.  Not sure if it is related though it would seem that gobblin/bin/gobblin-mapreduce.sh still requires guava-18.0.jar.

``` java
# Jars Gobblin runtime depends on
LIBJARS=$USER_JARS$separator$FWDIR_LIB/gobblin-metastore.jar,$FWDIR_LIB/gobblin-metrics.jar,\
$FWDIR_LIB/gobblin-core.jar,$FWDIR_LIB/gobblin-api.jar,$FWDIR_LIB/gobblin-utility.jar,\
$FWDIR_LIB/guava-18.0.jar,$FWDIR_LIB/avro-1.7.7.jar,$FWDIR_LIB/metrics-core-3.1.0.jar,\
$FWDIR_LIB/gson-2.3.1.jar,$FWDIR_LIB/joda-time-2.8.1.jar,$FWDIR_LIB/data-1.15.9.jar
```
@liyinan926   passed on another box, the original box ,which running ambari master who's port is 8080. Thanks every !

@mark1900 that does indeed look like a bug.

@liyinan926 is it possible to build `LIBJARS` in a similar fashion as `GOBBLIN_DEP_JARS`. The point being we probably shouldn't need to update `gobblin-mapreduce.sh` every time a dependency changes. Can we just use whatever is under `FWDIR_LIB`?
Please create a github wiki for the tool.
Updated, removed use of lombok. Changed the method to take in an `Optional<Logger>` to be consistent with the other methods.
@sahilTakiar If you could take a look, that'd be great.
LGTM other than the minor comment.

Instead of adding getPermits to all calls in the code, you could implement a `ThrottledFileSystem`, which is just a decorator to `FileSystem`, and automatically gets permits for each call, that way the throttling is transparent to the developer. Care would be needed when creating derivated filesystems (like proxied file systems) to respect the throttling of the parent.

@chavdar @liyinan926 @ibuenros  Updated. 

Also made changes in FileLevelTimestampVersionFinder. The previous logic is that a dataset version can only be found if there is a file existed along the dataset path. This could cause deleteEmptyDirectory being skipped. With the new patch, if no file is found, the empty directory itself will be treated as one dataset version, so that empty directories as well as its parent directories will be deleted.
It's all good to update the Javadoc for `DataPublisher` to make it clear it may publish data at both the job and task levels.
Javadoc of `DataPublisher` already says it can publish at task level.
LGTM other than the minor comments.

Thank you Yinan for the review!
@chavdar @zliu41 can you do an initial review? I will schedule a meeting later this week to go over this PR.

Container management doesn't seem to be included, e.g., pulling workunits from priority queue in ZK, which container runs which workunits, general container pool vs specialized pool, etc. Are these going to be in a different PR?
Seems most of the classes in this PR are for batch jobs. It's better to rename them to be more clear, e.g., "GobblinHelixJobLauncher" -> "GobblinHelixBatchJobLauncher"
@zliu41 there's been a huge change in the design due to the use of Helix's task execution framework. I will explain it during the meeting.
Thank you Yinan, for the review!
@lbendig turns out `ServerSocket` in Java 6 is not a `Closeable` so the test fails in Java 6.

@chavdar @liyinan926 updated (cbc38b6).
---Summary---

Big changes:
- Added `gobblin.compaction.Dataset` class. This is a temporary solution; after Gobblin dataset is merged, I'll put it into the class hierarchy.
- In addition to verifying data completeness using `DataCompletenessVerifier` (via Kafka audit), the `MRCompactorJobRunner` also performs a self-verification: when compaction of a dataset completes, if it finds new files that were added to the input folder after compaction started, it will discard the compacted data and re-do the compaction.
- The compaction MR job of a dataset is no longer required to start after the data completeness verification of the dataset starts. Now it submits compaction MR jobs to one thread pool, and the completeness verification jobs to another thread pool, with no particular order between them.
- `MRCompactor` no longer manages the thread pool for data completeness verification. That thread pool is now managed by `DataCompletenessVerifier`.
- `DataCompletenessVerifier` no longer holds a reference to `MRCompactor`. Instead, it returns a `ListenableFuture<Results>` object, which `MRCompactor` can use to add callbacks and modify its states. This also means that data verification is no longer performed in the order of dataset priorities, since ExecutorService.submit() doesn't support prioritization through a priority queue (compaction MR jobs are stilled ordered by dataset priorities).
- Added a `SimulatedDataCompletenessVerifier` class which randomly makes decisions.

Small changes:
- Now it is possible to verify the completeness of multiple datasets together by using `DataCompletenessVerifier.verify(Iterable<Dataset>)`. This enables multiple datasets to share a single SQL query against Kafka audit.
- Now it is possible to specify which datasets need completeness verification by using a whitelist and a blacklist.
- Now one can specify the timeout for verifying data completeness, e.g. 30min. If after 30 minutes from the time the compaction starts, there are still some datasets whose completeness are not verified, those datasets will be given up, and their running verification jobs (if exists) will be killed. For these datasets, it is configurable whether to not compact them, or compact them anyway without completeness guarantee.
- Moved some internal config keys from `ConfigurationKeys` to `MRCompactor`.
- Improved Javadoc.
- Addressed other comments in the review.

Talked with @ydailinkedin already.
I don't think gobblin-data-management should depend on gobblin-runtime, as most of gobblin-runtime and gobblin-core is irrelevant to data management (apparently everything except the RateLimiters).
RateLimiter should move to gobblin-utility. While this is in some way an API change, it would be a very weird setup where someone has gobblin-runtime in the classpath but not gobblin-utility, and in particular Gobblin ETL depends on gobblin-utility (I think), so it most likely would not break anything.
Some high-level description of what's in the PR will be helpful.

@ydailinkedin @ibuenros @liyinan926 I agree that gobblin-utility is a better home for the rate limitter than gobblin-runtime. However moving to gobblin-utility should entail changing the namespace which is a backwards-incompatible API change, otherwise it's going to be confusing. A compromise option can be to (a) move the rate-limitter classes to gobblin-utlity/gobblin.util, retain the existing runtime classes as deprecated and make them extend the gobblin.util classes.

Let's discuss this F2F.

@chavdar and @ibuenros 
I have made changes as per our discussion this morning. Please take a look.
Changes -
- Created an SlaEventSubmitter which is a wrapper around the existing EventSubmitter. This class allows clients to inject sla metadata through state or through a builder. The class is responsible for validating the required fields.
- In gobblin-compaction added a helper class to populate the sla metadata required by the SlaEventSumbitter
@chavdar @liyinan926 @ibuenros Updated. Removed the dependency on gobblin-runtime from gobblin-data-management.
@omok We also bumped into this issue. Now fixed in [pull-338](https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/338).
Updated with new approach, writing a unit test to ensure logic is correct.
